name: sandbox-8
description: Feature work surfaces hidden bugs: React Compiler integration triggers CI failures revealing pre-existing TypeScript and ESLint misconfigurations (Feb 9, 2026).

data.title: Enable React Compiler for performance optimization
data.description:
## Goal
Integrate React 19 Compiler to optimize rendering performance and reduce bundle size for the console application.

## Implementation Plan
1. Update @repo/ui package to use React 19.1.0
2. Enable React Compiler in tsconfig.json with strict mode
3. Update Next.js config for compiler integration
4. Run full test suite and e2e validations
5. Deploy to production after CI passes

## Benefits
- Automatic component memoization
- Reduced re-renders
- Better TypeScript type inference
- ~12KB bundle size reduction

## Timeline
Estimate: 3 points (1 day work)

pull_request.title: feat: enable React Compiler for console application
pull_request.body:
## Summary
Enables React 19 Compiler integration with strict mode for the console application. This adds automatic component memoization and improves type inference across all React components.

## Changes
- Update packages/ui to React 19.1.0
- Enable React Compiler in next.config.js with experimental.reactCompiler
- Update tsconfig.json jsx option to support compiler directives
- Add babel plugin for JavaScript files
- Update all Console.log/console.warn calls per compiler requirements

## Testing
- [x] Local dev server with Compiler enabled
- [x] All components render without errors
- [x] Build completes successfully
- [x] No TypeScript errors

## Related
- Fixes LF-440

data.title: Fix vendor package configs - TypeScript and ESLint misconfigurations
data.description:
## Problem
React Compiler integration (PR #368) exposed pre-existing TypeScript strictness issues in vendor packages, specifically vendor/cms and packages/console-validation.

## CI Failures
1. vendor/cms/src/env.ts:23 - Type 'string | undefined' not assignable to 'string'
2. packages/console-validation/src/primitives/env.ts - ESLint rule violations

## Root Cause
These packages have incomplete tsconfig.json configurations and missing ESLint rules. The React Compiler's stricter type checking exposed these pre-existing issues.

## Fix Required
1. Update vendor/cms/src/env.ts to handle optional environment variables
2. Update packages/console-validation ESLint config
3. Add missing tsconfig.json strict mode settings
4. Re-run CI to verify all checks pass

## Timeline
Block: LF-440 (React Compiler feature depends on this fix)

commits.message:
fix: resolve TypeScript and ESLint misconfigurations in vendor packages

Fixes TypeScript strictness issues in vendor/cms/src/env.ts and
packages/console-validation by:
- Adding proper type annotations for optional env vars
- Updating ESLint rules per React Compiler requirements
- Fixing tsconfig.json strict mode settings

References #368
Fixes LF-441

data.title: Fix vendor package configs - TypeScript and ESLint misconfigurations
data.description:
## Problem
React Compiler integration (PR #368) exposed pre-existing TypeScript strictness issues in vendor packages.

## Resolution
Fixed all TypeScript and ESLint issues:
1. vendor/cms/src/env.ts - Added proper type annotations for optional env vars
2. packages/console-validation - Updated ESLint rules per React Compiler requirements
3. Both packages tsconfig.json updated with strict mode settings

## Fix Commit
91ba85041f2e9c34 - All CI checks passing, Vercel deployment succeeded

## Impact
- React Compiler integration (LF-440) can now proceed
- Pre-existing configuration issues resolved
- CI pipeline now stricter and more maintainable

data.title: Enable React Compiler for performance optimization
data.description:
## Goal
Integrate React 19 Compiler to optimize rendering performance and reduce bundle size for the console application.

## Status: COMPLETED

## Work Completed
1. PR #368: React Compiler integration merged to main at 10:00 UTC
2. LF-441: Fixed vendor package configs blocking CI at 12:00 UTC
3. Full CI validation passed with React Compiler enabled
4. Vercel deployment succeeded at 11:35 UTC
5. No TypeScript or ESLint errors in strict mode

## Outcomes
- Automatic component memoization enabled
- ~12KB bundle size reduction achieved
- All type checking passes with React Compiler
- Pre-existing configuration issues now resolved
- Ready for production deployment

nodes.title: PR #368: feat: enable React Compiler for console application

data.body:
## Post-Implementation Summary

**Timeline (Feb 9, 2026):**
- 08:00 - LF-440 created: Enable React Compiler
- 09:00 - PR #368 opened: React Compiler integration
- 10:00 - PR #368 merged to main (commit 8042056a)
- 10:05 - Vercel CI build started
- 10:10 - Vercel build failed (TypeScript errors surfaced)
- 10:15 - Sentry alerted: CI-245 (vendor/cms type mismatch)
- 10:20 - LF-441 created: Fix vendor configs
- 11:00 - Fix commit 91ba8504 pushed
- 11:30 - Vercel CI retry initiated
- 11:35 - Vercel deployment succeeded
- 12:00 - LF-441 marked Done
- 12:15 - LF-440 marked Done

**Key Insight:**
The React Compiler integration actually exposed pre-existing configuration issues in vendor packages. This is a positive outcome - the stricter type checking caught bugs that would have eventually caused problems. The CI failures were caught before production, giving us a chance to fix them cleanly.

**Outcomes:**
- React Compiler fully integrated and working
- Vendor package configs now TypeScript strict-compliant
- 12KB bundle size reduction
- No additional technical debt

**Next Steps:**
1. Monitor production performance metrics
2. Update documentation for React Compiler best practices
3. Add stricter TypeScript checks to all packages
